tossups.question: One battle in this war was named for Africa Point, a swampy knoll where a handful of soldiers were killed while gathering wood for Fort LaMotte. Another skirmish in this war became known as “Spur’s Defeat” after a report was released about one side digging their spurs into their horses to escape; that clash was a failed attempt to avenge the Pigeon Roost Massacre. At a place known as Sindathon’s Village, the forces of Thomas Van Horne were ambushed in this war; the ensuing Battle of the Oakwoods featured general Adam Muir solidify his rout at the Battle of Brownstown. Duncan McArthur’s raid at the Battle of Malcolm’s Mills ended a theatre of this war, which included the siege of Prairie du Chien. Another surrender led to the court-martial of William Hull and the battle at the River Raisin. For 10 points, name this war during which Isaac Brock captured Fort Detroit with help from Tecumseh.
tossups.answer: War of 1812 [accept Tecumseh’s War before Tecumseh is mentioned, or the “Detroit frontier of the 1812 War” since that’s what the question is about]

tossups.question: In a film by this director, subjects are interviewed while standing next to a lightbulb hanging from the ceiling. This director made a satire of the film Hardcore in which Frank Gorshin plays the pimp Walsh against Trish Van Devere’s concerned mother. In another film by this director, the "Citizens Against Crime" clash with runaways who brand themselves with the letters “T.R.” at a Vandals concert. This director adopted Eyeball, one of the subjects of a sequel to a 1981 film which Daryl Gates tried to ban from Los Angeles; that film’s first sequel is subtitled “the metal years.” This director of Hollywood Vice Squad, Suburbia, and The Boys Next Door became pigeonholed as a director of Saturday Night Live vehicles after she made a film featuring a scene inside an AMC Pacer in which five men sing “Bohemian Rhapsody.” For 10 points, name this director of the Decline of Western Civilization and Wayne’s World.

Alan Grob's A Longing Like Despair claims that this poem illustrates the pessimism of its author since its second-half describes "bursting figs" and "tunnies steep'd in brine" but no people. The speaker of this poem describes a society “whose vague resolves never have been fulfill’d” and who “hesitate and falter life away.” This poem’s speaker claims that “repeated shocks, again, again, / exhaust the energy of the strongest souls” but the title figure is “free from the sick fatigue, the languid doubt”. The title character was “born in days when wits were fresh and clear” in a time before the "strange disease of modern life” in this poem in which the speaker awaits “the spark from Heaven” as described in "[Joseph] Glanvil’s book.” At its beginning, the speaker tells a shepherd that “they call him from the hill.” For 10 points, name this poem about a former Oxford student, written by Matthew Arnold.

Mutations in the gene STOX1 are associated with susceptibility to this condition. Recent studies have had conflicting results about the potential usage of podo·cyturia as a diagnostic marker for this condition. Though the cause of this condition is unknown, it is associated with altered levels of soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1, endoglin, and PLGF, indicating it may be caused by imbalanced regulation of angio·genesis. A variant of this condition is characterized by a triad of elevated levels of LDH and trans·aminase enzymes, hemolysis, and low platelet count, and is known by the acronym HELLP syndrome. Magnesium sulfate can be used to treat extreme forms of this condition, which is characterized by protein∙uria and hypertension. For 10 points, name this condition which afflicts 2-8% of women in the third trimester of pregnancy, which, when untreated, can lead to seizures.

An erroneous statement in the Quran about this man’s genealogy is pointed out by the Christians of Najran, after which Muhammad calls this man a “pious person” whom people name their children after. According to Surah Taha, this man would have prevented one of the crimes he perpetrates in the Bible, but was fearful of being accused of causing division among the Children of Israel; that deed of this man is instead attributed to Samiri. The Quran curiously places this man’s tomb in Petra, and identifies Mary as his sister. In Mormonism, the Presiding Bishop heads an order named for this man; members of that order, upon turning 18, enter into a more powerful priestly order named for Melchizedek. The Biblical account of this man’s life states that he died atop Mount Hor, is the ancestor of the Kohenim, and constructed the Golden Calf. For 10 points, name this older brother of Miriam and Moses.

At this work’s climax, a fortissimo B dominant 7th chord is followed by a pianissimo A minor chord and brief minor-key coda. Poetic excerpts including the lines “the fuel is all consumed / and the hearth is cold and dark” were originally published with its score. This work’s most famous theme is first presented over halfway through by unison fortissimo horns, and begins with a leap up an octave to a long G, followed by the descending line [read slowly] F, E, D-F, E [short pause] D. This piece is based on an unfinished verse play of Nikolaus Lenau. It begins on the “e” of beat 1 with an infamously difficult C major unison upward flourish for the strings, before lurching into the home key of E major. This work was composed alongside a work based on Macbeth, and was followed by its composer’s Death and Transfiguration. For 10 points, name this tone poem by Richard Strauss that depicts a womanizer.

Supposedly, when this artist was a child, his father Elmer tied rope around his ankles and lowered him into a well in Bow Island, Alberta. This painter co-founded an artist’s colony at the Coleville Indian Reservation, where he made Indian Houses, Nespelem. Barbara Ramsay, a conservator, estimates that about 10% of this artist’s paintings suffer from peeling paint, partly caused when this artist “practices his stabbing” on his canvases. Five ghostly figures, including one holding an apple, stand behind a kneeling woman in this artist’s unusually realistic PH-76. The largest collection of the paintings of this artist can be found in a namesake museum in Denver. Like Josef Albers, this artist used a palette-knife to apply thick paint to create jagged, amorphous shapes. 1957-D No.1 is one of the characteristic color-field works of, for 10 points, what artist best known for his black and yellow paintings?

A character in this novel tries to "bury himself with books" by studying furiously for a year, but fails, causing him to "sink into deep gloom" by drinking sake. At its conclusion, that character notes that the painter Watanabe Kazan postponed his own death to complete his painting Kantan, explaining why he took ten days to write a letter. In the second section of this novel, the narrator becomes estranged from his elder brother in Kyushu, and abandons his dying father to take a train to Tokyo. This novel largely follows a man who visits a grave in Zoshigaya once a month, and who was cheated out of his inheritance by his uncle. The narrator of this novel learns that a young man named K. killed himself after his best friend proposes to a landlady's daughter. This novel, whose title is often translated as "heart of things", centers on a recluse called Sensei. For 10 points, name this novel by Natsume Soseki.

Supporters of preserving this policy set up a 20-member “caretaker executive” led by two brothers from Longford. This policy was inspired by the actions of Hungarian and Czech officials after the Revolution of 1848, as outlined in the booklet The Resurrection of Hungary. Despite achieving a historic first for women, Constance Markievicz complied with this policy. Supporters of this policy staged a 1970 walkout during a vote to end it and formed an “Official” splinter wing of their party, later renaming themselves the Workers’ Party. This policy, initially supported by Arthur Griffith’s plan in 1905, led to a split that formed the Fianna Fáil under Eamon de Valera. Gerry Adams insists on pursuing this policy, though ending it could break a potential coalition. For 10 points, name this policy, by which elected members of an Irish party refuse to take oaths of allegiance and participate in Parliament.
tossups.answer: Sinn Féin’s abstentionism [accept word forms, such as Sinn Féin abstaining from Parliament; accept any answers that indicate both Sinn Féin and refusing to serve in Parliament]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Matthew Nimetz was made a negotiator during this conflict, which led to a participant being blocked from attending the 2008 Bucharest Summit. A proposed solution to this dispute involves the use of the Vardar River. To avoid escalating this disagreement, Oliver Stone shot a 2004 film in Thailand and Morocco. This conflict was exacerbated by the VMRO’s policy of antiquization, which included the construction of statues like Warrior on a Horse and the Founder of Heraclea in Bitola. An agreement in this conflict, the 1995 Interim Accord, forced a participant to replace a flag that shows the Vergina Sun. To avoid inflaming this conflict, the U.N. uses the acronym F.Y.R.O.M. to refer to one of the countries involved. An announcement to rename Skopje airport re-ignited, for 10 points, what between two countries which claiming to be descendants of Alexander the Great?
tossups.answer: Macedonian naming dispute [accept any answers that mention a dispute between Greece and Macedonia; prompt on answers relating to the heritage of Alexander the Great or Philip II of Macedon]

tossups.question: The integrals for the phase-space function describing this phenomenon can be written in a closed form by using the Primakoff-Rosen approximation, which yields the result that the phase-space function is independent of charge. There may be multiple possible internal mechanisms for this phenomenon, according to Schechter and Valle's "black box theorem." The GERDA and KamLAND-Zen experiments are attempting to observe this effect using germanium-76 and xenon-136, respectively; those nuclei are useful for observing this effect since the pairing force makes them exceptionally stable. Physics beyond the Standard Model involving lepton number violation caused by a purported Majorana fermion is required to explain how this effect can occur without emitting a neutrino. For 10 points, name this process in which two neutrons are transformed into two protons and two electrons.
tossups.answer: neutrinoless double beta decay [prompt on beta decay or neutrinoless beta decay]

tossups.question: This book posits that men were extremely wise before the "birth of wisdom", praising the "child" and the "savage of California" who "does not know thinking". In discussing a basis for metaphysics, the author of this text asserts "there is almost no other absolute truth, except that all is relative". This text, which wonders if the alphabet was accidentally invented by the ancients, states "everything in man is a habituation". First published in 1898 with extensive notes by Giosue Carducci, it outlines a philosophy of despair, arguing that for a true man, "the idea of society is a contradiction in terms". Michael Caesar and several other editors spent seven years producing the first English translation this text, which consists of jottings collected between 1816 and 1830. A word meaning a "hodge-podge of thoughts" gives its name to, for 10 points, what massive text consisting of Giacomo Leopardi’s notebooks?

The reverend of this city, Emmanuel Heath, wrote a firsthand description of an event here where the ship Swan was wrecked and a landslide at Judgment Cliff destroyed 800 meters of land. William Link infamously excavated a Blondel pocket watch frozen at the time of 11:43 AM in this city, which was originally a small community known as Cagway. The Giddy House is a red brick artillery fort in this city, which has been tilted by quicksand. Governor Edward D’Oley invited a group called the Brethren of the Coast to make their base in this city, which served as the capital of its colony until it was moved to Spanish Town. Sometimes called the “Sodom of the New World,” this city is where Calico Jack was hanged, a couple decades after it was destroyed in 1692 by an earthquake. For 10 points, name this city once run by Henry Morgan, a haven for pirates in British Jamaica.

Paola de Michelis examined the 1991 “jerk” affecting this structure, tying it in part to the Wolf Number. The CHAMP satellite provided a model of this structure truncated at the 10th degree, yielding 120 coefficients that describe it. That model of this structure is an alternative to the WMM, which can be found in almost all mobile phones. A “knee” in the power-spectrum of this structure was found by Langel and Estes who were examining Mauersberger and Lowes’ work that fitted variance of this structure using Gauss coefficients. A westward drift rate of about .2 degrees per a year comprises this structure’s secular variation, as given by the IGRF model. The Laschamp Event is one of many excursions that affect the strength of this structure. The Vine-Matthews-Morley Hypothesis theorizes that there are reversals of, for 10 points, what vector field that is generated by Earth’s dynamo?
tossups.answer: geomagnetic field [accept b-field of the Earth; prompt on B-Field or magnetic field]

tossups.question: Trends in this activity for union households in the PSID were analyzed in a 1995 paper by John Shea. It’s not discounting, but a 2001 paper by David Laibson and others proposed a “hyperbolic” model to explain long-term time-inconsistent tendencies in this activity. Time-series data on this activity was reinterpreted to show that about half of people follow a present-centric “rule of thumb,” in a 1988 paper by Campbell and Mankiw. Using rational expectations theory, this activity was shown to be stochastic and thus follow a random walk, in a 1978 paper by Robert E. Hall. John Maynard Keynes proposed a “fundamental psychological law” that a number between 0 and 1 always represents the “marginal propensity” to perform this action given a change in income. According to Milton Friedman, expected or “permanent” income determines a person’s level of—for 10 points—what action, the opposite of saving?
tossups.answer: consumption [accept consumer spending; accept word forms like consume; accept marginal propensity to consume]

tossups.question: Mura Dehn documented this place’s workers and clientele in the documentary The Spirit Moves. The alleged gangster Moe Gale provided the funding to build and open this place, which was managed by Charles Buchanan. This place is described as “just like a clinging vine / so soft, and sweet like wine” in a song by Edgar Sampson. Numerous “battles” with Chick Webb at this location led Buddy Rich to call Webb the “daddy of them all.” Many of the workers at this place were part of a group founded by bouncer Herbert White, who was nicknamed “Whitey”; that group starred in films such as A Day at the Races. A remark by Lana Turner led the nickname “the home of happy feet” to be applied to this place, where the Lindy Hop was supposed first performed. Louis Armstrong had a top 10 hit with a song about “stompin’ at” this place. For 10 points, name this ballroom in Harlem.
tossups.answer: Savoy Ballroom [accept Stompin’ at the Savoy]

tossups.question: In an essay, this country is praised for its “indefatigable workers” that are similar to “splendid fighting animals.” The author of that essay describes living with a merchant from this country who overcharged him 30 cents for a measure of corn. That essay says people from this country are not cowards since one of them can chase down a soldier to retrieve a large pear. In a story from the collection Strength of the Strong, an author claims “work” was the breath of the nostrils of this country’s people. In that story, Burchaldter’s estimations that this country has 5 million people leads to a plan to have tiny airships drop glass tubes filled with plague-carrying mosquitos to effect a genocide in it organized by Jacobus Langingdale. For 10 points, name this country that Jack London wrote about in “The Unparalleled Invasion”, which is also the setting of the novels Sons, A House Divided, and The Good Earth by Pearl Buck.

Warning: Specific Title Required. A ruler with this title placed the head of a statue of an opposing emperor at the entrance of a palace, so that anyone who entered had to step on that opponent’s head. The ornate burial site of a holder of this title, designated N6, was recklessly destroyed by Giuseppe Ferlini. A relief at the Temple of Apedemak in Naqa depicts a holder of this title named Amanitore about to strike enemy soldiers. In retribution for a conquest by a holder of this title, the city of Napata was destroyed. An account from the Alexander Romance claims that a holder of this title intimidated Alexander the Great into retreating north. Strabo described how Syene and other cities of Roman Egypt were briefly conquered from Augustus by a one-eyed holder of this title named Amanirenas, who ruled from the capital, Meroë. For 10 points, give this title held by the female rulers of Kush.
tossups.answer: Kandake of Kush or Candace [accept Qore of Kush; prompt on Queen of Kush or Nubia]

tossups.question: This element aromatizes phenyl∙decalin in the last step of a synthesis of phe·nan·threnes named for Bardhan and Sengupta. Two phosphorus atoms and four atoms of this element link two benzene rings in Woollins' reagent. The 3-prime UTRs of proteins containing this element include a hairpin structure with two loops bridged by a core containing 4 non-Watson-Crick base pairs. Phenyl oxides of this element can be used to synthesize alkenes via reactions like the Grieco elimination. This element is found in the active sites of iodo·thy·ronine de∙io∙dinase, mammalian thio∙redoxin reductase, and gluta∙thione peroxidase. A compound of zinc and this element was used to make the first blue LED. A compound of cadmium and this element is often used in quantum dots. For 10 points, name this element which, in non-standard versions of the amino acids methionine and cysteine, replaces sulfur.

A philosopher from this country analogized public opinion to a scalar quantity and the general will to a vector quantity in a book proposing a “General Will 2.0”. That man from here theorized that a certain group engages in “passive” animalesque consumption and “active” humanesque consumption of information in databases. Another philosopher from here proposed a kind of “effortless naturalness” to combat “despair of self-power”, and a sort of anti-philosophy called meta·noetics. In turn, he inspired another philosopher from this country who suggested that all things must have a “place” in his essay From that which Acts to that which Sees, and who pioneered the use of “absolute nothingness”. Rea Amit once illustrated this country’s aesthetic concepts, such as a kind of "perfection" and "imperfection" called wabi-sabi, using images of one and two ahoges (uh-hoh-”gays”). For 10 points, name this country of origin of Hiroki Azuma and Kitaro Nishida.

bonuses.leadin: In this country's most famous work of literature, Taramalu is forced to swim around a rock until she can point to the rock from any direction since she learns to discern waves from the "four swells of the world". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country whose poem "Taramalu and La Enjen" was first translated into English by Gerald Knight. That poem from this country was recited by its most famous author known as "Man This Reef".

On this other island chain, bards would engage in the art of apo, or "catching literature", the art of memorizing poems upon first hearing them. Maxine Hong Kingston wrote The Woman Warrior after moving here.
Polynesian literature also includes this country's native Maori poems. Its more modern authors wrote the story "The Garden Party" and the novel the bone people.

bonuses.leadin: The last-known whereabouts of the “Twin Sisters” cannons are in this city, where they were used at an 1863 battle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city, where the Union Navy intentionally sank USS Westfield after another ship, Harriet Lane, was captured. Juneteenth commemorates the abolition of slavery by Gordon Granger from a balcony in this city.
The “Twin Sisters” were first used at this 18-minute battle, where Sam Houston effectively won the independence of Texas from Mexico.

In 1831, the Mexican government lent this town a cannon to deter Comanche raids. An 1835 attempt to recover that cannon led to the first battle of the Texas Revolution, where a flag with the Lone Star and the words “COME AND TAKE IT” was flown, leading this town to be dubbed the “Lexington of Texas.”

bonuses.leadin: Because the edges of this entity are not obvious, one can characterize their size by the displacement thickness or the momentum thickness. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these regions of flow near a surface, in which viscous effects are significant. They were conjectured by Ludwig Prandtl to avoid d'Alembert's paradox.
According to the Blasius model, the displacement thickness for a laminar boundary layer is proportional to this quantity raised to the negative one-half power.

When a fluid enters a pipe, the boundary layers grow and eventually meet as the fluid moves through the pipe. Beyond the point where the boundary layers meet, this two-word term describes the flow regime, since the velocity profile doesn't change with length.

bonuses.leadin: William Schuman based the second movement of his New England Triptych on this melody. For 10 points each:
answers: shape [accept shape note hymns or shape note singing; accept more specific answers such as printing notes in the shape of a square or diamond or triangle or wedge or something not a circle (or oval)]
parts: Name this song written in the 18th century by William Billings. The second of its two couplets of lyrics claims that when the title figure “groaned” “a trembling fear / seized all the guilty world around.”

“When Jesus Wept” is one of these “tunes” popular in colonial-era America for polyphonic group singing. Despite what their name implies, they were actually performed in the manner of a simple round or canon.

19th-century American music printers made singing easier for the musically-illiterate by altering this general feature of noteheads to indicate which pitch they represented, such as in the collections Southern Harmony and The Sacred Harp.

bonuses.leadin: Roman Jakobson used the languages aphasics of these people to develop “structural laws” about “phonological universals.” For 10 points each:
answers: children [accept reasonable equivalents or subsets like kids, infants, toddlers, etc.; accept answers like child language]
language acquisition [accept reasonable equivalents; accept “learning a second language”]
parts: Name these people. In a 1971 paper, Peter Eimas et al. studied “Speech perception in [these people]” using a synthesizer programmed with different conditions of voice onset time.
Children’s babble is often studied to better understand this general process, whose stages are denoted “L1,” “L2,” etc. This process has to have happened twice before code-switching is possible.

This Harvard psychologist wrote a study of the “early steps” of language learning called A First Language. He co-wrote the paper that coined the term “flashbulb memory” with James Kulik, and published a study of color words with Eric Lenneberg.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about history, punctuation and the history of punctuation, for 10 points each:
parts: This Princeton historian and biographer of Joseph Scaliger wrote “a curious history” of The Footnote, tracing its use from the development of citations in the scientific history of Leopold von Ranke to its obsessive modern usage.
The first footnote in Grafton’s book cites the work of G.W. Bowersock, which concerns this historian’s use of footnotes in his History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.
This author was the first to suggest to Gibbon that his endnotes in Decline and Fall be published as footnotes. He published a history of England during the years from 1754 to 1761.

bonuses.leadin: This city may have been known as “Kattigara”, meaning the “Strong City”, and some scholars have identified it with Cottiaris, a city cited by Ptolemy in his Geographia. For 10 points each:
answers: Hinduism [accept word forms; accept Vaishnavism or Vaishnava Hinduism]
parts: Name this archaeological site whose name means “Glass Canal.” It may have been an entry point for Roman coins minted during the reign of Antoninus Pius into the kingdom of Funan.
Funan was one of the earliest Southeast Asian states to practice this religion. Angkor Wat, whose five towers represent the five peaks of Mount Meru, was originally a temple for this religion.
Southeast Asian historian Georges Coedes noted that both Funan and this Javanese dynasty used the title “King of the Mountain.” This Buddhist dynasty built the massive temple of Borobudur.

bonuses.leadin: This text contains the earliest known manuscript illustration of the Crucifixion as well as a Peshitta Gospel Harmony set within columns. For 10 points each:
answers: Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry [or The Very Rich Hours of the Duke of Berry; accept the Duke of Berry’s Book of Hours; prompt on Book of Hours]
parts: Name this 6th-century illuminated set of Gospels that was written at the Syriac monastery of Saint John of Zagba by the namesake monk.

This devotional manuscript created by the Limbourg brothers was elaborated by a painter known as the Master of the Shadows. Philip of Savoy sent Jean Colombe to present this manuscript to a French nobleman.
This French painter illustrated a Book of Hours on commission from Étienne Chevalier. He also created the Melun Diptych.

bonuses.leadin: When this character is introduced, the narrator states “Glory be to god for dappled things” to describe her freckles. For 10 points each:
answers: The Obscure Object [prompt on The Object]
parts: Name this high school girl, the best friend of Callie. Callie explores her budding sexuality with this character, whose moniker is a reference to a Luis Bunuel film.
Cal Stephanides’ sexuality is treated at length in this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Jeffrey Eugenides.

Tim Morris argues that Middlesex is a contender for the Great American Novel, as is this other author’s novel about J. Sutter’s investigation into a festival centering on a postage stamp, John Henry Days.

bonuses.leadin: The van Laar equations are used to calculate these quantities indirectly in terms of the excess Gibbs free energy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity, denoted gamma, which accounts for non-ideal behavior in solutions. When it equals 1, Raoult's Law holds.
According to the Debye-Huckel limiting law, the natural log of the activity coefficient of an electrolyte scales with this power of the ionic strength.

This thermodynamic model for activity coefficients of binary mixtures is similar to the Wilson model, but it describes partially miscible systems well due to including a parameter denoted "alpha-1-2." When that parameter is zero, this model reduces to the two-suffix Margules equations.

bonuses.leadin: One of the expressions of this standpoint is David Lewis’ paper “Elusive Knowledge”. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this philosophical position. It holds that the truth of person T’s claim that person S ‘knows’ p, is contingent on the state of affairs of the claimant T.
This philosopher attacked contextualism in Knowledge and Lotteries, a book which develops an epistemological theory that inverts the attributor-subject relationship of contextualism.

Contextualism attempts to skirt round the skeptical problem by pointing out that it dissolves as a relevant issue in ordinary use cases. This philosopher refuted the sceptical argument by shifting it from a modus ponens to modus Tollens with his “here is one hand” argument in the paper “Proof of an External World”.

bonuses.leadin: These events are followed by secondary succession when they occur naturally and periodically in the chaparral. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this specific kind of ecosystem disturbance, which are often performed in a controlled fashion by humans to preserve an ecosystem's natural cycles of biodiversity.
Wildfires occur at three different levels: ground fires, surface fires, and this high-intensity type of fire, which spreads from treetop to treetop and is difficult to control.

Some plants in ecosystems with natural wildfires have adapted by adopting this behavior, in which seed dispersal doesn't occur upon maturation, but instead occurs in response to an environmental trigger.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about bonfires in mythology:
answers: Nuwa and Fuxi [or Nugua and Paoxi]
throw a rabbit at him [accept any answer which mentions a rabbit being flung at him]
parts: Bonfires are circled the night before Holi and during a Hindu wedding in honor of this seven-tongued fire god.

In Chinese myth, these offspring of Hua Hsu married after two bonfires they created merged together. One of them cuts off the legs of a turtle to prop up the heavens, while the other teaches humans how to hunt with spears.

When Tecciztecatl is too afraid, the humble god Nanahuatzin becomes the fifth and final Aztec sun by jumping into a bonfire. After Tecciztecatl also jumps in out of pride, there were two suns – so the gods were forced to do this to Tecciztecatl to dim his light and turn him into the moon.

bonuses.leadin: Thomas Hubbard studied "intertextuality" and "literary filiation" in works of this genre in his study The Pipes of Pan. For 10 points each:
answers: Arcadia [accept the Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia]
Jorge de Montemor [prompt on partial answers; they need both parts]
parts: Name this genre of poetry and plays that takes its name from a word meaning "shepherd". These works include Torquato Tasso's Aminta and include the idylls of Theocritus.

Jacopo Sannazaro's 1504 poem of this title is often considered to be Renaissance poem that popularized the pastoral. A romance of this title includes a double sestina between the shepherds Klaius and Strephon.
The first truly popular pastoral prose work is a seven book Romance about Sireno's love for the title character, and is titled Diana, which was written by this Portuguese author.

bonuses.leadin: At the end of this event, the defendant was acquitted of murder but ordered to pay one franc each to the widow and brother of the victim. For 10 points each:
answers: Schwarzbard Trial [or trial of Sholom-Shmuel Schwarzbard]
parts: Name this 1927 French court case in which a namesake Jewish-Russian anarchist provided justification for killing Symon Petlura, the architect of pogroms in 1919 and 1920.
The Petlura pogroms took place during the chaotic post-World War I environment of this present-day country, where Stepan Bandera later collaborated with Nazis after the Holodomor.

During the multi-factional fighting in Ukraine, this peasant led the “Black Army” which protected the anarchist Free Territory in Ukraine’s southeast. A book by Alexandre Skirda refers to him as “Anarchy’s Cossack.”

bonuses.leadin: This photograph was made after its creator was hired by the Farm Security Administration. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this photo taken by Gordon Parks. It depicts the cleaning lady Ella Watson with a broom and mop in front of the U.S. flag.
Gordon Parks' social justice photos were often featured in this magazine. Its first magazine cover showed Margaret Bourke-White’s photo of Fort Peck Dam.
Parks’ success at Life paved the way for this photographer, who also worked for the magazine. He collaborated with Langston Hughes on the fiction book The Sweet Flypaper of Life.

bonuses.leadin: In A Fine Old Conflict, this author relates an anecdote about a paranoid Communist Party member who refused to say that chickens could be bought in Petaluma out of fear of listening devices. For 10 points each:
answers: Jessica Mitford [or Decca Mitford; prompt on Mitford]
funeral industry [or burial industry or undertakers or morticians]
parts: Name this activist whose exposes included a 1970 takedown of the Famous Writers School and the satire “Life∙itself∙manship,” which discusses “L and non-L English” to parody the linguistic tics of the Communist Party.
Mitford’s best-selling book was a 1963 expansion of her muckraking article "Saint Peter Don't You Call Me,” which criticized the aggressive sales practices of this industry.

Mitford wrote a chronicle of the 1968 trial of the leaders of the anti-Vietnam movement RESIST, including this lifelong friend of George H.W. Bush. He preached liberal causes as the senior minister of Riverside Church in Manhattan from 1977 to 1987.

bonuses.leadin: This book is formed from some "condensed novels", one of which depicts the suicide of Marilyn Monroe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book, whose 1990 edition included an appendix containing "The Secret History of World War III". It concerns a character named Talbot or Travis or Travers, and explores aspects of his schizophrenic mind under headings such as "The University of Death" and "Notes Toward a Mental Breakdown".

The Atrocity Exhibition by J. G. Ballard also contains a section in which the protagonist explains why he wants to fuck this man, whose salacious hairstyle apparently has led people to compare it to their own pubic hair.
In the final section of The Atrocity Exhibition, this man's act of murder is compared to a "Downhill Motorcycle Race". This assassin is also the subject of Don Delillo's novel Libra.

bonuses.leadin: A Boolean function has this property if negating the function is equivalent to negating each of its individual variables. For 10 points each:
answers: self-dual [do not accept or prompt on “dual”]
parts: Give this term. In another context, the tetrahedron, but not the other four Platonic solids, has this property.
In group theory, unimodular lattices, which have a determinant of 1 or -1 are inherently self-dual. This unimodular lattice in 24-dimensional space solves the kissing number problem.

Desargues’ theorem, which relates axial perspectivity to central perspectivity and vice versa, is self-dual and applies to the geometry described by this term. Parallel lines intersect at “infinity” points in the plane of this name.

bonuses.leadin: This family first found success after fleeing to Cornello from Bergamo, which was plagued by a Guelph-Ghibelline feud. For 10 points each:
answers: Thurn und/and Taxis [or de la Tour et/and Tassis; accept Tasso]
parts: Name this family including Eugen Alexander Franz that produced many postmasters for various Holy Roman Emperors, including Charles V. They ran an early widespread postal service throughout Europe.

The family gained a stronger foothold after Mary the Rich signed this charter in 1477, which restored the local right of governance to the Dutch towns of Flanders, Brabant, and Holland, removing the restrictions previously demanded by the Dukes of Burgundy.

A Thurn und Taxis post in this city was where a black, red, and yellow tricolor was first flown in 1848. In that same year, a parliament held in this city ultimately failed to unify Germany under Frederick William IV.
